title: Concave or Standing Woman
creditLine: Gift of Frank C. Springer, Jr. in memory of his wife, Irving Moxley Springer
galleryLabel: This female figure, an elegantly abstracted form from the prime of the artist's career in Paris, reflects Archipenko's innovative exploration of form and space, void and concavity.\nAs Archipenko observed: "in art the shape of the empty space should be no less important than the meaning of the shape of solid matter."
provenance: Purchase from Perls Gallery, New York, on April 6, 1962, by Frank C. Springer, Jr. and Irving Moxley Springer, Indianapolis, for $2,070\nPartial gift to the IMA from Frank C. Springer, from 1991 through 2006.

title: The Artist's Party
creditLine: Gift of the National Coalition of 100 Black Women, Indianapolis Chapter and Mr. Kim Anderson and the Estate of Hermine Floch by exchange
galleryLabel: Delaney combines aggressive brushwork, exaggerated poses and a tendency toward caricature to suggest the group's animated conversation.\nDelaney is shown with his back to the viewer talking to a man believed to be the Abstract Expressionist painter Jackson Pollock.
provenance: Collection of Derek Beard; ACA Galleries

title: Training for War
creditLine: National Coalition of 100 Black Women, Indianapolis Chapter, Estate of Hermine Floch by exchange and James E. Roberts Fund
galleryLabel: Johnson's style consists of flat, simplified patterns presented in a na茂ve manner with a touch of humor.\nThe artist pokes fun at the army's regimentation and discipline.\nPochoir is a stencil technique characterized by crisp lines and brilliant colors.
provenance: Thurlow Tibbs, Washington, D.C.; purchased from dealer Craig F. Starr Associates

title: Mushrooms on a Blue Background
creditLine: The Robert and Traude Hensel Collection
galleryLabel: With its rapid brushwork and tilted perspective, this painting summons a strong sense of motion.\nHartley worked in France in the late 1920s, where he produced numerous still lifes.\nThe artist was a member of the Stieglitz Group of American Modernist artists.
provenance: Bernard Dannenberg Gallery in New York; Mrs. Francis Phipp Mallek from the estate of the artist

title: Woodcutters in Windsor Park
creditLine: Gift of Mrs. Nicholas H. Noyes
galleryLabel: Born in Pennsylvania, Benjamin West studied painting in Rome in his early twenties and moved to England in 1763, where he remained for the rest of his career. The setting for this landscape is the Queen's Lodge in the Great Park at Windsor, where woodcutters are shown making a clearing to provide a "view." Such vistas were an essential part of 18th-century English landscape design. The landscape was painted the same year West began work on a major cycle of decorations for the chapel at Windsor Castle.
provenance: (back to top)Provenance Research is on-going at the Indianapolis Museum of Art, and information will be added to this record as research is completed. Please contact Annette Schlagenhauff, Assoc. Curator of Research, at aschlagenhauff@imamuseum.org with any questions.

title: Pelvis with Distance
creditLine: Gift of Anne Marmon Greenleaf in memory of Caroline Marmon Fesler
galleryLabel: The radical manipulation of perspective and scale, and the strong but elegant contours of the bone, exemplify O'Keeffe's genius for capturing the essential forms of nature.\nIn 1929 O'Keeffe began to summer in New Mexico, where the colors, shapes, and vistas of the Southwest became central to her work.
provenance: Purchased from the artist by Caroline Fesler; Anne Marmon Greenleaf 1960; donated to the IMA 1977

title: Ruth Gleaning
creditLine: Gift in honor of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Fortune by their children and Gift of the Alliance of the IMA
galleryLabel: The statue's elegant face and poised bearing have the grace and dignity of the neo-classical ideal.\nRogers was a member of the neo-classical movement considered to be America's first native school of sculpture.\nRuth was an Old Testament heroine who left her birthplace and settled in Israel, uttering the words, "Whither thou goest, I will go."
provenance: Purchased in Italy in the mid-1930s; collection of gaetano Lancellotti, Rhode Island until 1987; sold to the museum through Conner-Rosenkranz

title: Marianne Ashley Walker
creditLine: Gift of Mrs. Nicholas H. Noyes
galleryLabel: Stuart endows his subject with character and elegance through sheer technical facility, which is evident in Walker's exquisitely rendered flesh tones and lifelike eyes.\nThis portrait was painted on the occasion of the sitter's marriage.
provenance: Daniel H. Farr; John Levy Gallery in New York 1933; given to the museum in 1952

title: Reflections
galleryLabel: Reflections features the circular shapes, natural forms and feathered brushstrokes that are hallmarks of Dove's style.\nDove, an artist known for his humor and whimsy, said that this painting was about reflections from headlights on the windshield of a car.\nThe artist was a key member of the Stieglitz Group of modernist painters and a pioneer of abstraction.
provenance: The artist; Alfred Stieglitz in New York; The Downtown Gallery in New York; collection of Mr. and Mrs. Denman Bellevue WA; private collection; corporate collection; purchased from Alexandre Gallery in 2003 by the IMA

title: Sunlit Window
creditLine: Gift of the Louis Ritman Estate
galleryLabel: Ritman's interest in decorative patterning is evident in the mixture of floral prints with stripes that contrast with the buzzing confusion of nature seen through the open window.\nRitman, a Chicago artist, settled in Giverny, France near the home of Claude Monet, in 1909.
provenance: Donated to the museum by the Louis Ritman estate through Maurice Ritman

title: Frog Fountain
creditLine: Gift of the Woman's Department Club
galleryLabel: This nude figure of a child surrounded by a base of frogs was inspired by children Scudder observed in Italy.\nScudder was one of the premier artists of garden sculpture of her era.\nFrog Fountain is Scudder's best-known work.
provenance: ...purchased (from the artiist?) by the Women's Department Club in 1928.  It was donated to the IMA by the club in 1984

title: Thornberry's Pasture
creditLine: Gift of Robert Brady Adams, John Alban Adams, and Edward W. Adams
galleryLabel: In this landscape Adams pursues the impressionist goal of capturing the light and atmosphere of a specific moment.\nThornberry's Pasture is in Brooklyn, Indiana a few miles southwest of Indianapolis.\nAdams was the first painting instructor at the John Herron Art Institute.
provenance: Owned by Winifred Brady Adams (wife of the artist); given to the museum by the sons of the artist

title: Untitled
galleryLabel: Famous for his mobiles and stabiles, the sculptor Alexander Calder was also a notable painter.\nCalder's work displays a free and whimsical spirit.\nThe two keyhole-shaped vibrantly colored, geometric figures transform a simple design into a dream image.
provenance: ...purchased from Ann Kendall Richards in New York 1971; authenticated by Mr. Klaus Perls of Perls Gallery in New York

title: Venus Anadyomene
creditLine: Gift of Dr. and Mrs. M. D. Ratner
galleryLabel: The stylized hair and soft rounded forms are in harmony with the images of the sea, the goddess, and Art Deco sculpture of the 1920s and 1930s.\nThis small bronze figure is tied to the mythological goddess of love and her birth from the foam of the sea.
